FTUE/ftue_first_eva_msg_1: Your Kerbal is now outside of your vehicle doing an EVA or Extra-Vehicular Activity. You can move them around either on foot or by deploying their jetpack.
FTUE/ftue_first_eva_msg_2: To learn more about EVA, visit the Training Center tutorial called One Small Step.
FTUE/ftue_first_maneuver_msg_1: You’ve added a maneuver plan! Maneuver plans predict the result of a burn at a set orientation and duration. Once you’ve placed a plan, you can use it as a guide for your next maneuver.
FTUE/ftue_first_maneuver_msg_2: You can learn more about maneuvers at the Training Center. Check out the tutorial called Orbital Transfers for more info.
FTUE/ftue_first_overheat_msg_1: Oh no! A part of your vessel has been destroyed by overheating! Parts can heat up due to air friction, internal heating, or proximity to a heat source.
FTUE/ftue_first_overheat_msg_2: To learn more about heat and heat shields, check out the tutorial Orbits are Weird at the Training Center.
FTUE/ftue_first_recoverable_msg_1: You've successfully landed! You can recover your vessel through the Escape Menu. When you recover your vehicle, your vehicle will be recycled, and your crew returned to KSC for their next mission.
FTUE/ftue_first_recoverable_msg_2: When you recover your vehicle, your vehicle will be recycled, and your crew returned to KSC for their next mission.
FTUE/ftue_flight_msg_1: Are you ready to fly? Here are a few pointers.
FTUE/ftue_flight_msg_2: This element is your flight cluster. It contains all of your flight controls and information.
FTUE/ftue_flight_msg_3: Here you can speed up or pause time. You can still move your camera and interact with part functions when you’re paused.
FTUE/ftue_flight_msg_4: This is your Staging Stack. It shows the order in which your rocket’s parts will activate. Remember that the first stage is at the bottom of the stack!
FTUE/ftue_flight_msg_5: If you’d like to learn to fly in a safe, simulated environment, be sure to check out the Training Center!
FTUE/ftue_launch_too_big_msg_1: Be sure that your vehicle’s parts don’t go through any of the walls, floor, or ceiling – your launch assembly must fit completely inside of the VAB before it can be launched!
FTUE/ftue_launch_too_big_msg_2: You can review your launch assembly’s dimensions in the Engineer’s Report.
FTUE/ftue_lost_commnet_msg_1: This vessel is out of communication range with KSC. Your controls are limited while you can’t communicate back home.
FTUE/ftue_lost_commnet_msg_2: You can either move your vehicle within communications range of KSC, or you can move another vehicle between this position and KSC to relay your signal back home.
FTUE/ftue_lost_power_msg_1: Many systems on your vehicle consume Electric Charge or EC. Without power, none of these can function. This readout shows you how much Electric Charge remains.
FTUE/ftue_lost_power_msg_2: To learn more about electrical power, check out the tutorial Orbits are Weird at the Training Center.
FTUE/ftue_map_msg_1: This is the Map View, which shows you the positions and flight paths of every vehicle, object, and celestial body, no matter how far it is from home.
FTUE/ftue_map_msg_2:
Feel free to zoom in and out to get a better look at things. Double-click to focus on any object.
  
Holding middle mouse down will allow you to freely move the camera. Reset the camera with Home.
FTUE/ftue_map_msg_3: If you select a point at a vehicle’s trajectory, you can place a maneuver plan at that location. This lets you predict the outcome of a future maneuver, and it tells you when and how to perform it.
FTUE/ftue_map_msg_4: If you’re curious about maneuvers, the Training Center teaches you how to create and execute them.
FTUE/ftue_map_msg_5: If you want to change focus to a new vehicle, object, or celestial body, you can do that in the Tracking Station.
FTUE/ftue_new_game_msg_1: Hello, and welcome to Kerbal Space Center! This campus has everything you need to turn your fledgling space program into the stuff of legends.
FTUE/ftue_new_game_msg_2: Our engineers have created a training program that will guide you through building and flying your very first rocket. You can go through those lessons here at the Training Center.
FTUE/ftue_new_game_msg_3: If you want to start building right away, the Vehicle Assembly Building is where you want to be!
FTUE/ftue_new_game_msg_4: Are you playing in Exploration Mode? Be sure to visit Mission Control! Completing missions is one way to earn Science, which will let you purchase technologies at the R&D Center.
FTUE/ftue_new_game_msg_5: First time? Swing by the Training Center to learn the basics!
FTUE/ftue_tracking_station_msg_1: This is the Tracking Station! From here, you can easily find and learn more about your vessels and celestial bodies.
FTUE/ftue_tracking_station_msg_2: You can find any tracked object here. By default, they are sorted by position, so you can find all ships orbiting Mun under the Mun.
FTUE/ftue_tracking_station_msg_3: Selecting an object will show the Information Panel. This will give you detailed information: it’s really handy for planning missions to new celestial bodies.
FTUE/ftue_tracking_station_msg_4: You can perform actions on your vessels here too! This is the place to be if you want to change what vessel you’re actively flying.
FTUE/ftue_training_center_msg_1: The Training Center is where we go to learn how to build and fly rockets, planes, and rovers.
FTUE/ftue_training_center_msg_2: As your program grows, the Training Center will grow with you. If you’re ever stuck, check the Training Center to see if any new lessons have been added!
FTUE/ftue_training_center_msg_3: Lessons take place in a simulation, and you can start a lesson at any time - even in the middle of an active flight! When you’re done, we’ll put you right back where we found you.
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_1: Welcome to the Vehicle Assembly Building, or VAB! This is where you assemble vehicles to take you wherever you want to go.
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_2: This is the Parts Picker. You take pieces from the picker and place them in your Workspace. A good starting rocket has a Command Pod, an Engine, and a Fuel Tank holding the fuel the engine needs. You can view parts by category. You can also search and sort parts! By default, parts are sorted by type. If you have a part you use often, you can add it to your Favorites by clicking the middle mouse button.
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_3: If you have a part you use often, you can add it to your Favorites by clicking the middle mouse button.
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_4: You can construct several assemblies, or sections of your vehicle, at the same time. The assembly marked with the green icon is your Launch Assembly. It is what goes out the door when you select Launch.
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_5: Use the Engineer's Report to see how your vehicle will perform. It will give you useful stats and a list of potential problems. For example, you can use the Engineer's Report to see if you have a thrust to weight ratio over 1, which means your rocket will actually leave the launch pad!
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_6: Over here is the Trip Planner. Use it to plot a destination and ensure that your vehicle has the ability to get there!
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_7: Once you’re ready to fly, select the Launch button. As long as your vehicle fits completely within the VAB, it will be moved out to your chosen launch location.
FTUE/ftue_vab_msg_8: The Training Center teaches everything from basic rocket construction to orbital mechanics. It’s both fun and informative!
FTUE/ftue_vessel_stranded_msg_1: Your vehicle is out of fuel! You can no longer change its course.
FTUE/ftue_vessel_stranded_msg_2: If you’d like to make another attempt at this flight, you can revert to launch and try again. You could also launch a rescue mission to dock with this vehicle and refuel it!
FTUE/ftue_vessel_stranded_msg_3: To predict whether your vehicle can get to its destination, you can learn more about Delta-V at the Training Center. Check out the tutorial Rocket Tips for details!
Tutorials/Lessons/Descriptions/Tutorial: Learn the basics of rocketry.
Launch and control a preconstructed rocket.
Attach parts to construct a rocket in the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB).
Control the camera in the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB).
Launch and stage a rocket to understand what stages are.
Read your rocket's altitude using the Altimeter and manipulate time using Time Warp.
Safely land and recover a command pod by using a parachute.
Test your skills by launching and landing a successful suborbital flight.
Learn how to miss the ground and make an orbit.
Learn how to use the Stack Decoupler part to stage a vehicle.
Learn how to attach radial Boosters and radial Decouplers to a vehicle using Symmetry Mode in the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB).
Learn how to customize the Staging Stack in the Vehicle Assembly Building (VAB).
Learn how to use the Navball to make a Gravity Turn.
Learn how to point a vehicle Prograde using the Stability Assist System (SAS).
Learn how to open the Map and to circularize to make an orbit.
Learn how to change your orbit.
Learn how to expand an orbit to reach high orbit.
Learn what Electric Charge (EC) is and how to generate it.
Learn how to deorbit.
Learn about heat and how to avoid overheating during an atmospheric re-entry.
Learn what is involved in traveling to another celestial body.
Learn how to time a departure from Kerbin to reach the Mun.
Learn how to perform a maneuver to transfer an orbit from one celestial body to another.
Complete an orbital transfer from Kerbin orbit to a stable Munar orbit
Tutorials/Lessons/Descriptions/Tutorial1: Build, launch, stage, and land a rocket in a suborbital flight to learn the fundamentals. We all have to start somewhere!
Tutorials/Lessons/Descriptions/Tutorial2: The goal of any Space Agency should be to get to space, right? Build and launch a rocket capable of reaching orbit.
Tutorials/Lessons/Descriptions/Tutorial3: So, you're in orbit, now what? There are many things to do in orbit: perform experiments for Science, travel to other planets or moons, and when you're ready, return home!
Tutorials/Lessons/Descriptions/Tutorial5: You've mastered orbits around Kerbin and now the universe beckons.
Tutorials/Lessons/Titles/Tutorial5/Maneu: Maneuver Nodes, Departure Timing, and Spheres of Influence
Tutorials/tutorial_1.0_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to go to space
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.10_msg_1:
Nice pitch! Now pitch up until you’re flying straight up!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=83></voffset></mspace> to pitch your rocket’s nose upward.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.11_msg_1: Let’s move on. Yaw steers your rocket left and right. Try it now! Press to yaw your rocket to the right.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.12_msg_1:
Now yaw to the left to straighten up.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=65></voffset></mspace> to yaw your rocket back to the left.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.13_msg_1: Excellent! Now for the final control. Roll rotates your rocket clockwise and counter-clockwise. Try it now! Press or to rotate your rocket around.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.14_msg_1:
That’s the basics of rocket flight!
  
Feel free to experiment with the controls. We can move on when you’re ready.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Select Continue when you’re ready to move on.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.1_msg_1: Welcome to the Launchpad! As you embark on your journey into rocketry, it’s important to get all the crashing out of your system here in the simulator. It really cuts down on the awkward phone calls. Today you’ll be launching into the virtual skies over KSC, where you’ll learn how to control a rocket.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.2_msg_1: Let's learn how to rotate the flight camera. That way, you can see the launch from your favorite angle! Rotate the camera by moving the mouse while holding down right mouse button.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.3_msg_1: Great! You can also zoom the camera in and out. Zoom in and out by moving the scroll wheel up and down.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.4_msg_1: Nice! Go ahead, pick your favorite view for this launch.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.5_msg_1: Your rocket is ready for launch! Every good launch starts with a big green button and lots of fire. Most bad launches do too, actually! Start the launch sequence by selecting the GO button or pressing the spacebar.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.6_msg_1: Looking good! Ascend to 1000 meters, and then we’ll start to learn some controls.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.7_msg_1: Looking good! Ascend to 1000 meters, and then we’ll start to learn some controls.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.8_msg_1:
Okay, you’re a kilometer up. You can still crash, but you’ll have more time to correct your course if you start pointing at the ground.
  
Let’s learn some rocket controls!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1.9_msg_1: When flying a rocket or a plane, we have specific terms for moving. Pitch tilts your rocket’s nose up and down. Press to pitch your rocket’s nose downward.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1_msg_failure_early: Oops, you launched too early, let's restart.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1_msg_failure_partd:
Those were some nice fireworks! 
  
If you loved the feeling of blowing stuff up, feel free to keep replaying this tutorial until you’ve had your fill. If you really, really loved that feeling, you may want to consider transferring to the fuel research department.
  
But if you’ve had enough, you’re all clear to go on to the next lesson!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.1_msg_failure_vehic:
Those were some nice fireworks! 
  
If you love the feeling of blowing stuff up, feel free to keep replaying this tutorial until you’ve had your fill. If you really, really loved that feeling, you may want to consider transferring to the fuel research department.

Tutorials/tutorial_1.1_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to move the camera in flight
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to launch a rocket
