Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.1_msg_1: So, you want to get to space? It’s time to make a rocket!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.2_1: A command module allows us to control our vessel. As long as there is at least one command module on board, our rocket will be operational! This rocket will use a command pod, which can be manned by a Kerbal and is located in the Pods Category. Or multiple Kerbals! It all depends on the crew capacity of the part.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.2_2: For this lesson we’re going to make a small rocket, so we need a small command pod. Let’s add this one. Select the Mk1 “Tin Can” Single Seat Command Pod.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.2_3: Great! It doesn’t look like much, but it’s a promising start! The next thing our rocket needs is a fuel tank. Fuel, or propellant, is an expendable resource used to power our vessels. Without fuel we won’t be going anywhere, let alone space. Let’s look at the small fuel tanks. Select the Fuel Tank Category in the Parts Menu.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.2_4: How about that one? Rocketry Weekly calls it, “good enough.” How exciting! Select the “FL- T400” Fuel Tank.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.2_msg_1: A simple rocket requires four crucial components, a command module, fuel tank, engine, and parachute. Let’s start by learning how to add a command module.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.3_1: Now that’s beginning to look like a rocket! Well, almost. We need an engine. Here at the KSP we have four different types of engines: launcher, sustainer, orbital, and deep space engines.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.3_msg_1:
Notice the part is once again attached to your cursor. If you place your cursor near the bottom of your command pod, you’ll see it snap into place. Then left-click to attach it.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Attach the fuel tank underneath the command pod.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.4_msg_1: To break free of Kerbin’s soupy atmosphere, we want either a launcher or sustainer engine. I personally like sustainers. What can I say? They keep me going. Select the Engine Category in the Parts Menu.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.5_msg_1: Now let’s add the sustainer engine to the fuel tank. Select the LV-T45 "Swivel" Sustainer Methalox Engine and attach underneath the fuel tank.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.6_msg_1:
Excellent! Our rocket is looking pretty great! We just need one final touch. As is, our rocket can absolutely take flight, but if we want our pilot to survive the landing, we need to attach a parachute to the top of their command pod. 
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Select the Utility Category in the Parts Menu.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.7: Our one Kerbal rocket doesn’t weigh much, so we only need an extra-small parachute. Let’s go with that one. Select the MK16 parachute.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.8:
Now all we need to do is put it on top of the command pod. It won’t do us much good on the bottom.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Attach the parachute to the command pod.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2.9: Congratulations, you’ve just built a rocket! Are you sure you haven’t done this before?
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2_msg_failure_partd:
Hmmm, did you remove a piece? Let’s go back to the original design.
Please restart this tutorial.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.2_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> Rockets need a command module, fuel, engine, and a parachute
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> There are four engine types (launcher, sustainer, orbital, and deep space)
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to find parts in the Parts Menu
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to attach parts
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.1_msg_1: As you start to build rockets, you will want to see your designs from other angles. Let’s learn how to manipulate the camera inside the Vehicle Assembly Building.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.2_msg_1: First, let’s rotate the camera. Hold down right mouse button and move the mouse to rotate the camera around your rocket.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.3_msg_1: Nice! Now let’s zoom the camera in and out. Scroll the mouse wheel forward and backward to zoom in and out.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.4_msg_1: Great! Now let’s pan the camera up and down. Hold the middle-mouse button and drag up and down to move the camera vertically.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.5_msg_1: You can also focus your camera at a specific part. Middle-click the mouse on any part of the vehicle to focus the camera there.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.6_msg_1: If you want to view your rocket from the top, front, or sides, switch to Blueprint Mode. You can change the camera’s direction by selecting different sides of the View Cube! Select the View Cube to activate Blueprint Mode.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.7_msg_1: If you ever get lost in the VAB, you can always reset the camera. Press the key to reset to the default camera view.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3.8_msg_1: Nice! Now you can get at those hard-to-reach parts of your rocket.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3_msg_failure_vabex: Oops, let's stay in the VAB!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.3_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to move the camera in the VAB
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to access Blueprint Mode
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to reset the camera
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.11_msg_1:
Ready? Hit GO to lose that mass!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press spacebar or click the GO Button to activate the next stage.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.13_msg_1: Congratulations! You’re nearly to space, and your next fuel tanks are empty. Now is a good time to drop them.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.14_msg_1:
Activate the next stage to separate those tanks.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press spacebar or click the GO button to activate the next stage.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.15_msg_1: Your capsule will now continue coasting up. All that’s left to do is gaze back down at Kerbin and wonder if you remembered to lock your car. Nice work!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.1_msg_1: Your rocket’s ready. Let’s take it out for a little hop!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.2_msg_1: Let’s move this rocket to a launchpad! Select LAUNCH to move the rocket from the VAB to the Launchpad.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.3_msg_1: Welcome to the launchpad! Today you’ll be flying straight up. Your rocket should do fine without any steering inputs, but if things get out of line somehow, feel free to intervene! Press spacebar or click the GO Button to launch. Press , , , , , and to steer your rocket.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.4_msg_1: You’ve cleared the launch tower, and your flight is underway! Let’s learn about staging. Rockets are constructed in sections called stages. Each stage is designed for a different part of a mission. When a stage completes its job, it’s dropped to shed weight.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.5_msg_1: You’ve cleared the launch tower and your flight is underway! Let’s learn about staging. Rockets are constructed in sections called stages. Each stage is designed for a different part of a mission. When a stage completes its job, it’s dropped to shed weight.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.6_msg_1: On your right, you’ll find the Staging Stack - it displays all of the functions contained in each stage. Every time you select the GO button, you’ll activate a new stage, starting from the bottom of the stack.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.7_msg_1: Each stage’s fuel supply is shown on a bar next to the stage. Your active stage – Stage 1 – still has a little fuel in it. When it goes dry, you’ll drop that stage by selecting GO.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.8_msg_1: Your first stage is out of fuel, and all it is doing is slowing you down. To drop that weight, you’re going to activate your next stage. That will activate a decoupler, which will drop your empty stage. It will also activate your next engine. Once you activate a stage, there’s no going back!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.9_msg_1: Your first stage is out of fuel, and all it is doing is slowing you down. To drop that weight, you’re going to activate your next stage. That will activate a decoupler, which will drop your empty stage. It will also activate your next engine. Once you activate a stage, there’s no going back!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4.x_msg_1:
Before we launch, there are two items I need to mention. First, you can click the green Arrow to the left of the GO Button. This lets you view your rocket's fuel. 
  
Second, unless you're a skilled pilot, I recommend you enable the Stability Assist System or SAS. SAS assists in stabilizing your rocket in-flight to help it stay on course. 
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press T to enable it.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4_msg_failure_partd: Your rocket needs all its parts. Please try again!
Your rocket needs all its parts. Please try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4_msg_failure_partr: Your rocket needs all its parts. Please try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4_msg_failure_vehic: While it’s technically true that space is in all directions, it’s very difficult to take a shortcut through the ground. Let’s try that again!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.4_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to launch and steer a rocket
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> What stages are and how to activate them
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5.1_msg_1: Your capsule has a lot of momentum! If you’re curious how high up you are, take a look at your altimeter. You’re so high that you can see the curve of the horizon!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5.2_msg_1: Rocketry involves a lot of waiting between the cool explosions. You can speed up time by selecting the Time Warp controls at the bottom of your screen. Press the key or select the second arrow in the Time Warp controls to activate 2x Time Warp.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5.5_msg_1: Check out your altimeter - see how quickly those numbers are rising? Let's ride the rest of the way up in fast-forward.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5.6_msg_1:
You’re about to start falling back down. Let’s slow down and enjoy the view.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press the <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=32></voffset></mspace> key or select the first arrow in the Time Warp controls to return to 1x Speed.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5.8_msg_1: Great job! You are now a master of time. Try not to use this new power for evil!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5._msg_failure_vehi: Oh well! On the plus side, you’re giving my explosion simulators a nice workout. Shall we try again?
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5_msg_failure_vehic: Oh well! On the plus side, you’re giving my explosion simulators a nice workout. Shall we try again?
Tutorials/tutorial_1.5_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> The altimeter measures distance from a celestial body
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> Where the altimeter is located
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> Time can be sped up and slowed down
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.10_msg1:
Another happy landing! I knew you could do it. Even if your Kerbal is a simulation, I am sure they are very hungry.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> End the mission by selecting the Recover Vessel button.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.10_msg_1:
Another happy landing! I knew you could do it. Even if your Kerbal is a simulation, I am sure they are very hungry.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> End the mission by selecting the Recover Vessel button.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.11_msg1: Nice! You've recovered your vessel and can view a full mission report.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.11_msg_1: Nice! You've recovered your vessel and can view a full mission report.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.12_msg_1: Nice! You've recovered your vessel and can view a full mission report.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.1_msg_1: What goes up must come down! Wind resistance will slow down your capsule’s descent, but not enough to prevent it from turning into a bunch of tiny capsules when it lands. That’s why we’ve attached a parachute!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.2_msg_1: If you deploy your parachute too early, it’ll be torn off. If you deploy it too late, you’ll do some unplanned underground exploration. The sweet spot for Kerbin is between 20,000 and 2000 meters.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.4_msg_1: Okay, you’re low enough to activate the final stage that contains your parachute.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.5_msg_1:
Hit GO to pop your chute!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press spacebar or click the GO button to activate your final Stage which contains the parachute.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.6_msg1: Nice work! The parachute will trail your capsule for a bit without fully opening – once you’ve slowed down enough it’ll open all the way by itself.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.6_msg_1: Nice work! The parachute will trail your capsule for a bit without fully opening – once you’ve slowed down enough it’ll open all the way by itself.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.8_msg1:
Your parachute is now fully deployed and slowing the capsule to a safe velocity!
  
Congratulations! If this were real, you’d find celebratory snacks in the VAB kitchen!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6.8_msg_1:
Your parachute is now fully deployed and slowing the capsule to a safe velocity!
  
Congratulations! If this were real, you’d find celebratory snacks in the VAB kitchen!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6_msg_failure_partd: Oops, looks like you’ve staged your vehicle too many times. Let’s try that again.
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6_msg_failure_vehic: Oh dear! Well, you did successfully make contact with the ground. Let’s try again, but a little slower this time!
Tutorials/tutorial_1.6_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That atmospheres slow down vehicles.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That parachutes use the atmosphere to slow down vehicles.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That parachutes must be opened at the right time.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That parachutes partially deploy and then open fully close to ground.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.0_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> What an orbit is.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to achieve orbit.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That we launch vertically to cut through the atmosphere quickly.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That rockets perform gravity turns to conserve fuel.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.10_msg_1:
Perfect!
  
Merging is a very powerful tool. Anytime you want to re-use a particular booster, lander, or other element from an existing rocket, merging saves you the hassle of making the same thing over and over.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.1_msg_1: When you’re making a rocket, it’s often easiest to work top to bottom, tailoring each stage to carry the weight of everything above it. To give you a head start, I’ve already placed an upper stage, perfect for maneuvering in the vacuum of space. It could use another, more powerful stage to push it up to space from Kerbin’s surface. Let’s turn this vehicle into a multi-stage rocket!
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.2_msg_1: Any time we intend to drop an empty stage after using all its fuel, we connect it to the stage above it using a decoupler. A decoupler contains explosive bolts that, when activated by a staging action, eject the attached stage away from the rest of the vehicle. Select the Coupling category in the Parts Picker menu.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.4_msg_1: Add that decoupler to the bottom of your rocket. Connect the TD-12 Stack Decoupler to the bottom of the rocket.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.5_msg_1: We need to attach a larger, more powerful lower stage to the bottom of your rocket. To keep things simple, I’ve whipped up a new lower stage in another workspace. You can bring saved vehicles and other subassemblies into an in-progress workspace by merging it. Let’s merge my lower stage into this VAB workspace. Select Load Workspace.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.6_msg_1: Out in the real world, this list would show all your saved workspaces. Here in the simulator, I’m only showing you the lower stage you need to merge. Select the Atmospheric Lower Stage workspace.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.8_msg_1:
Now that the lower stage has been merged into your current workspace, you can see it next to the upper stage. 
  
Select the lower stage and connect it to the decoupler beneath the upper stage to create a single two-stage rocket.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Select the lower stage.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1.9_msg_1: Attach the lower stage beneath the TD-12 Stack Decoupler.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.1_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> When to add stack decouplers.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to merge workspaces.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.10_msg_1:
Since you’re still in 4x symmetry mode, simply attach this booster to one of the decouplers you just placed. That will attach copies of that booster to the remaining decouplers.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Attach the RT-10 "Hammer" Solid Fuel Booster to one of the radial decouplers.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.11_msg_1: Great job! You've finished your orbital rocket! You can symmetrically place up to 8 parts at once - a feat that could until now only be achieved by certain sea creatures!
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.1_msg_1: Space rockets sometimes need an extra boost. In a rare case of rocket scientists naming something well, these additional rocket engines are called boosters. Boosters are attached to the sides of a vehicle to keep them out of the way of the main engines. Solid fuel rockets make great boosters – they produce a very high thrust for a short time. Let’s attach some boosters to the sides of your vehicle.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.2_msg_1: We’ll start by attaching four radial decouplers that will eject the spent boosters when they’re empty. To make sure that these decouplers are evenly spaced and aligned with one another, you’ll be using the Symmetry Tool. Right-click the Symmetry button in the Tools Bar.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.4_msg_1: Great! Now when you place a part on one side of your rocket, three more evenly-spaced duplicates will appear around the rocket. Go ahead and add four radial decouplers. Select the Coupling category in the Parts Picker.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.6_msg_1: Attach the TT-38K Radial Decoupler to the side of the highlighted fuel tank on the lower stage.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.7_msg_1: Perfect! Now you’ve got four radial decouplers exactly where they need to be.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.8_msg_1:
Let's attach those solid fuel boosters.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Select the Engine category in the Parts Picker.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2.9_msg_1: Scroll down and select the RT-10 "Hammer" Solid Fuel Booster
Tutorials/tutorial_2.2_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> When to use radial decouplers.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to place symmetrical parts.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to add solid fuel boosters.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.1_msg_1: Before you launch a rocket, you need to plan the order of your staging events – nobody wants to start out their flight by popping their parachute, right? Most parts that can be staged are automatically assigned to stages. Their activation order can be seen in the Staging Stack. You can change when staging events occur by moving them between stages. You can also add, remove, and reorder stages. Best of all, you can do this in both the VAB and in flight!
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.2_msg_1: The staging order begins at the bottom of the Staging Stack. You want your boosters and main engine to fire together for maximum thrust. The solid fuel boosters are currently in the second stage. If we don’t change anything, the boosters will ignite late and detach themselves at the same time. This would be embarrassing for everybody, so let’s move the boosters down to Stage 1. Move the 4 solid fuel boosters from Stage 2 to Stage 1 by clicking and dragging the booster icon in the Staging Stack.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.3_msg_1:
Just like that! Make sure both boosters are in the first stage.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Move the remaining solid fuel booster from Stage 2 to Stage 1 by clicking and dragging the booster icon in the Staging Stack.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.4_msg_1: Your solid fuel boosters burn very hard and very fast, so they will run out of fuel first. Even though your main engine and boosters will activate at the same time, you want to drop the empty boosters before you drop your main engine. You’ll add a new stage above Stage 1 to do one thing: activate the radial decouplers to jettison your spent boosters. Click the Plus to the left of Stage 1 to create a new Stage.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.5_msg_1:
Now move all four radial decouplers from Stage 4 to your new Stage 2.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Move the 4 radial decouplers from Stage 4 to Stage 2 by clicking and dragging the decoupler icons in the Staging Stack.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.6_msg_1:
Make sure you got all four decouplers moved to Stage 2.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Move the remaining radial decouplers from Stage 4 to Stage 2 by clicking and dragging the decoupler icons in the Staging Stack.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.7_msg_0:
All done! Your remaining stages are set up so that Stage 4 will activate your orbital stage’s engine, Stage 5 will detach the orbital stage’s fuel tank when it’s empty, and Stage 6 will deploy your landing parachute. 
  
Thanks to you, this rocket is ready to fly!
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3.7_msg_1:
All done! Your remaining stages are set up so that Stage 4 will activate your orbital stage’s engine, Stage 5 will detach the orbital stage’s fuel tank when it’s empty, and Stage 6 will deploy your landing parachute. 
  
Thanks to you, this rocket is ready to fly!
Tutorials/tutorial_2.3_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to edit the staging stack.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to set up staging for parts that activate at the same time but decouple at different times.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.10_msg_1: <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Use the <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=68></voffset></mspace> key to yaw the vehicle eastward until the target marker is aligned with the level indicator.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.11_msg_1: Way to make Kerbin’s gravity work for you! You’re now on track to establish an orbit. Keep the rocket pointed at the target until the main engine runs out of fuel.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.12_msg_1:
Your current stage's fuel is empty. Let’s drop it and activate your deep-space engine.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press Spacebar or click the Go Button to activate the next stage.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.13_msg_1: Great job! Your rocket is on its way to orbit! As you gain experience, you can make your gravity turns more efficient by starting to tilt your rocket soon after liftoff. Adjusting course with a series of small corrections instead of one big one will leave you with a lot more fuel when you get to orbit. Turning immediately after launch requires a very stable rocket, so if you ever have trouble keeping the pointy end up, you can try the simplified wait-and-turn method we used today.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.14_msg_1: Great job! Your rocket is on its way to orbit! As you gain experience, you can make your gravity turns more efficient by starting to tilt your rocket soon after liftoff. Adjusting course with a series of small corrections instead of one big one will leave you with a lot more fuel when you get to orbit. Turning immediately after launch requires a very stable rocket, so if you ever have trouble keeping the pointy end up, you can try the simplified wait-and-turn method we used today.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.1_msg_1: Alright, we’re ready to light this candle! In this flight, you’re going all the way to orbit – I’ll walk you through the process of launching, executing a gravity turn to get moving sideways, coasting to orbital altitude, and doing a final burn at the top of your arc to establish a stable orbit.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.2_msg_1: Before we begin, let’s talk about the Navball. The Navball shows your vehicle's orientation relative to the horizon. The blue half of the ball represents the sky, and the brown half represents the ground. The level indicator at the center shows your vehicle's orientation. When you turn, the ball turns. When you roll, the ball rolls. Assuming you want your rocket pointed at the sky, you'll want to see lots of blue on the Navball. If you get confused, remember this rhyme: "If the Navball's brown, you're going down!"
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.3_msg_1: At launch, you want all your engines at maximum thrust, which means you need to set your throttle at 100%. Your solid fuel boosters are way ahead of you on this – they have no setting other than full throttle, and they can’t be shut off once they’re lit. Once you hit the “Go” button, they’ll go full tilt until they run out of fuel. Still, your main engine’s throttle is in your control.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.4_msg_1:
You can see your main throttle here. 
  
Left Shift gradually increases your throttle.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=47></voffset></mspace> gradually decreases your throttle. 
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=90></voffset></mspace> and <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=88></voffset></mspace> instantly set your throttle to 100% or 0% respectively. 
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=104></voffset></mspace>left Click on the throttle will set its level where you clicked.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set the throttle to 100% now.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.5_msg_1: Your fuel levels are visible within the Staging Stack. Right now you can see that your main engine and four boosters are all topped off and ready to rumble. It’s time to go! At the start, all you need to do is fly straight up. I’ll check back in with you once those boosters are empty. Good luck! Press spacebar or click the Go Button to launch!
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.6_msg_1:
Alright, the solid fuel boosters are empty. Let’s drop them.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press the Spacebar or click the Go Button to activate the radial decoupler stage.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.7_msg_1: It’s time to start your gravity turn. A gravity turn uses the pull of a planet’s gravity to help bend your vertical ascent into a horizonal arc. It’s the first step to entering orbit! For our first flight to orbit, we’re going to start our gravity turn up where the air is thin – at an altitude of around 10,000 meters. To show you where to aim your rocket, I've placed a target marker on your navball.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.8_msg_1: First, we need to get to 10,000 meters.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4.9_msg_1: You’re going to yaw towards the east so that the target marker is in the center of the navball. Your vessel and navball should look like this example video if you’re performing the gravity turn correctly. Press Continue when you’re ready.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.4_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> When to begin a gravity turn.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How far to pitch during a gravity turn.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That gravity turn timing can vary based on design and location.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.10_msg_1:
Okay, your orbit is fully out of the atmosphere. Cut the throttle!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set Throttle to 0% by pressing the <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=88></voffset></mspace> key, pressing and holding the Left Ctrl key, or by clicking the Throttle.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.11_msg_1: You did it! You’re in orbit! This is when I’d usually tell you to look under your seat in the simulator, where you’d find a delicious celebratory treat! Sadly, since the vending machine in the astrodynamics lab broke down, it has gotten very difficult to hide snacks anywhere at KSC. Feel free to take a moment to admire your first orbit. In a way, you’ve given yourself a Mind Snack, which is way better than the edible kind anyway, right? Right?
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.1_msg_1: Right now, we’re on a ballistic trajectory. If no further adjustments are made, your rocket will eventually fall back down to the ground. Our objective is to turn this arc into an orbit. The process of turning your trajectory into a circular orbit is called circularization. Partial credit to the rocket people on that one: it does have the word “circle” in it, but it’s really hard to say.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.2_msg_1: When planning and executing orbital maneuvers, you’ll want to switch to Map View, where you can see every part of your current trajectory. Press the key or select Map to open Map View. Scroll the mouse wheel down to zoom out.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.3_msg_1: The blue arc passing through your vehicle is its current trajectory - the path your rocket will follow if you don’t touch the controls anymore. Our goal is to make that arc into a circular orbit. After you’ve coasted nearly to the top of this arc, you’re going to point forward and then you’re going to ignite your engine. If you time this burn right, you’ll never quite get to the top of the arc, as it’ll keep widening in front of you until it wraps all the way around the planet!
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.4_msg_1: Let’s break that down a little more: The top of your arc has a helpful tag in map view - it’s called the Apoapsis, abbreviated as AP. You’re going to max out your throttle before you pass this point.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.5_msg_1: We’re paused at just before the apoapsis. We want to go faster in the direction we’re already moving, so we need to make sure our rocket is pointed forward. There’s a handy marker on your navball - called the Prograde marker - that represents your forward direction. Use the Stability Assist System, or SAS, to point your vessel at that marker. Select the Prograde button to aim the rocket forward.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.6_msg_1:
You’re all lined up and ready to go! The next step is to go to max throttle.
  
It can take time for your arc to fully expand into an orbit. If you look closely at where your trajectory meets the ground, you’ll see it moving toward the horizon. 
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set Throttle to 100% by either pressing the <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=90></voffset></mspace> key, pressing and holding the Left Shift key, or by clicking the Throttle.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.7_msg_1: Once your trajectory reaches all the way around the planet, you’ll see another marker on your orbit: this is the Periapsis (PE), the lowest point in your orbit. It’ll always live on the opposite side of your orbit from the apoapsis, or highest point. By burning prograde near your apoapsis, you increase the altitude of your periapsis, the lowest point of your orbit.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.8_msg_1: Here’s the most important thing to remember about setting up an orbit above an atmosphere: your periapsis must be higher than the atmosphere, or your rocket will start to slow down every time it dips into the upper atmosphere. On Kerbin, that means every part of your orbit must be higher than 70 kilometers.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5.9_msg_1: Keep your eye on your trajectory for now, and I’ll tell you your periapsis is safely out of the atmosphere.
Tutorials/tutorial_2.5_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to enter Map View.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That Prograde means along the forward vector.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That Apoapsis and Periapsis mean the highest and lowest points of a trajectory.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That increasing velocity prograde at apoapsis will increase periapsis.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That Kerbin orbit is achieved when periapsis is outside the influence of the atmosphere.
Tutorials/tutorial_2_failure_crashed: By my calculations, you need to go up to achieve orbit. Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_2_failure_deleted_par: That’s creative, but I think our rocket needs that piece. Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_2_failure_missed_turn: It's not a gravity turn if you don't turn! Let's try again.
Tutorials/tutorial_2_failure_no_fuel: Oh no, we’re out of fuel and simulated stranded! Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_2_failure_staged_earl: Every stage has its time, and this one was a little too soon. Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.0_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> You change velocity to change orbits.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> Change of orbit happens at the opposite side of where the change of velocity occurred.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.10_msg_1: Warping to a point will automatically use time warp so that you quickly and precisely reach your desired destination. You’ll spend a lot of time trying to reach specific points in your trajectory, so if you know where you need to be, just Time Warp to Point.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.11_msg_1: Now you’re way up in the sky - so high that if you circularize your orbit now, you’ll be in high orbit. Wow, Kerbal Space Center looks so small from here.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.1_msg_1: An equatorial orbit is good, but if you want to travel beyond Kerbin, you will need to manipulate your orbit. Let’s start with something simple: expanding an orbit. We do that by increasing the value of our Apoapsis. Let’s get a good view. Select to Enter Map View.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.2_msg_1: Remember how you circularized your orbit by increasing your forward velocity? To raise your orbit, you’ll just do more of the same. It’s time to burn prograde! Select Prograde on the SAS controls.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.4_msg_1:
Now that we’re pointed the right way, we can increase the throttle and watch our orbit expand.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Increase Throttle to 100%.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.6_msg_1:
Cut the throttle! If you overdo it, you’ll leave Kerbin orbit entirely!

<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Decrease Throttle to 0%.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.7_msg_1: Nice! That maneuver raised our orbit on the other side of Kerbin, so we will enter high orbit there. Waiting to reach a specific point can be as eventful as watching the neon stripes on your rover dry. The paint job will be worth it, but isn’t it better to rush to the end? Skip ahead to the good stuff using a time warp.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.8_msg_1: Like I said earlier, the highest point of our orbit is called the Apoapsis (AP). The lowest point of our orbit is known as the Periapsis (Pe). By default, your camera is focused on your vessel, so if you can’t see either of these points, adjust your camera.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.9_msg_1: Excellent! You can time warp to any position on your trajectory by selecting a point on your vehicle’s current path and then selecting Time Warp to Point. Select Time Warp to Point.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2.C: Scroll the middle mouse wheel to zoom in and out. Double click an object to center your camera on it. Click the middle mouse button to enter free cam. Press Home to reset the camera to your active vessel. Select the Apoapsis icon.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.2_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> To expand orbits.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> To time warp to a point in orbit.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> The Apoapsis (AP) and Periapsis (PE) are the highest and lowest points in orbit.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.10_msg_1: Having a source of Power to your rockets is vital to long term operation!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.1_msg_1: From command pods to space probe cores, a lot of critical rocket parts use Electric Charge (EC). You’ll want to design your rocket so it can generate and store EC.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.2_msg_1: Most rocket engines generate electric charge while active, but we’ll still need a way to keep our batteries full while coasting between maneuvers.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.3_msg_1:
Solar panels convert Kerbol’s light into EC for our rockets. Before these panels can do their thing, we need to deploy them.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Open the Part Manager.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.4_msg_1: Solar panels convert Kerbol’s light into EC for our rockets. Small solar panels can just be placed, but large solar panels are delicate and must only be deployed once we’re out of the atmosphere. I’ve equipped this rocket with two deployable solar panels. Here’s a hand crank, get to work!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.5_msg_1: Just kidding! There’s a handy button that opens all of your solar panels with a single click. Give it a try! Deploy Solar Panels by selecting Solar Panel button
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.7_msg_1: Great! The solar panels are now extended! Light-tracking solar panels only rotate on one axis, so we may need to reorient our ship to point them fully at the sun. Let’s make sure the panels are getting direct sunlight by rolling our ship a little bit. Use and to turn the vehicle so the solar panels are facing Kerbol.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.8_msg_1: Excellent! The solar panels are soaking up all of those sweet photons and giving our rocket some much-needed EC. You can see the status of any solar panel within the Part Manager in the Electrical Parts menu. You can either access the app directly by clicking the app button, or you can right-click a part to directly access it in the Part Manager.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3.9_msg_1: Getting EC is one thing, and storing it is another. Most command pods have a small battery, but many missions will call for additional EC storage. When we’re traveling far from the sun or going to the dark side of a planet, more batteries mean more peace of mind!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.3_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> What Electric Charge (EC) is.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to use Solar Panels to gain EC.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That Solar Panels do not work when far away from a star or on the dark sides of planets.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That EC can be stored in batteries.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.1_msg_1: At some point, the crew will run out of snacks. Did you know a Kerbal is 99.9% more likely to crash when hungry? That's when it’s time to head back down to Kerbin, a planet known for its plentiful snack options! First, let’s get a better view for this operation. Select to Enter Map View.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.2_msg_1: Remember how we burned prograde to raise our orbit? To lower our orbit, we burn in the opposite direction, retrograde. SAS can really help us out here, so let’s turn that on. Enable SAS.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.3_msg_1: Now flip retrograde, the opposite direction to our rocket’s movement. When we get into position to fire our engine backwards, we’ll slow down. Select Retrograde on the SAS controls.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.5_msg_1:
Alright, the rocket is aligned to retrograde. Increase the throttle and burn until our trajectory is just past the atmosphere! 
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set Throttle to 100%.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.6_msg_1: As we decelerate, watch what’s happening to our Periapsis (PE). Once it enters the atmosphere, this rocket is on a path back to the ground. Don’t ease off the throttle yet, though! We’re going to keep burning until our trajectory intercepts the ground. This should give us a good idea where our capsule will land.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.7_msg_1:
That’s it! Now let’s stop our burn. 
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set Throttle to 0%.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.8_msg_1: Now that we’re on a collision course with Kerbin, we need to turn that collision into a something more survivable. This process of crashing without dying is called “landing.” Our upcoming stage will activate a decoupler, dropping the engine and exposing a very important heat shield. Why don’t you do that now? Discard the engine by staging the rocket.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4.9_msg_1: Great! We’re on our way down, and our heat shield is exposed. Have you ever wondered what a marshmallow feels like when it catches on fire? You’re about to find out!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.4_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> What retrograde means.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That burning retrograde reduces your orbit.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> Once your orbit reaches the atmosphere, your rocket will deorbit.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5.1_msg_1: Okay, we're about to descend very quickly. Our friend, the atmosphere, doesn’t like speeding, and it’ll do everything in its power to slow us down. This tendency gets downright violent at re-entry speeds. Travelling rapidly through the atmosphere compresses the air in front of the vessel - slowing us down but generating heat. Re-entry is all about slowing down and diverting heat away from the sensitive parts of our vehicle. As our capsule descends, friction with the air generates heat.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5.2_msg_1: The only thing keeping us from becoming a shooting star is the disc-shaped heat shield beneath our capsule. Lucky for us, this capsule is equipped with one! Let’s start by selecting retrograde. Select Retrograde.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5.3_msg_1: Right now, SAS is keeping the ship pointed retrograde, meaning the heat shield is facing forward. It’s the only thing standing between our flammable crew and the white-hot blast furnace outside.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5.4_msg_1: Heat shields can take a beating, but they don’t last forever. As it's cooked by the heat of re-entry, it sheds expendable layers of material called ablator. Once the ablator’s all gone, your heat shield is as durable as a sheet of paper. Good thing you checked the durability before we took off. Right? Let’s watch the show!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5.5_msg_1:
Whew, that was intense! I'd sweat if I had any pores. Now our velocity is low enough to safely deploy the parachute! Go ahead!

<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Deploy the parachute by staging the rocket.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5.6_msg_1: Let’s savor this moment and make sure that our parachute fully deploys. If you want, you can use Time Warp to savor it quickly!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5.7_msg_1: Thanks to the heroic efforts of our heat shield, our parachute has fully deployed, and our crew will land in the correct number of pieces. Mission Accomplished!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.5_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:


<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That the heat shield protects your vessel.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> The heat shield must be facing towards the direction of re-entry.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to deploy a parachute
Tutorials/tutorial_3_failure_crashed: That is what we call an unplanned deorbit. Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_3_failure_deorbiting: You want to go back home now? There’s so much to do! Let’s try again.
Tutorials/tutorial_3_failure_no_fuel: Oh no, we’re out of fuel and simulated stranded! Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_3_failure_part_destro: I don’t have enough glue to fix that part. Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_3_failure_staged_earl: Every stage has its time, and this one was a little too soon. Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorial_3_failure_too_away: I know you want to explore, but now’s not the time to leave Kerbin! Let’s try again.
Tutorials/tutorial_3_failure_transmitted: Stop, stop! I want that science as much as you, but this is a simulation, and that science is not real. Let's try that again.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.10_msg_1: Nice! That maneuver event towards the end of your trajectory is exactly what we’re looking for. It says that if we execute this plan, we’ll intercept the Mun!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.11_msg_1: If a maneuver looks right but we’re not getting the intercept we expect, we can change the starting position of the maneuver by grabbing and dragging the middle of the maneuver plan along our orbit. It’s very common to refine a maneuver plan by adjusting both the position of the maneuver and the direction of the planned burn.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.12_msg_1: If you don’t want a maneuver at all, you can delete the plan either by right-clicking the gizmo and selecting delete or through the Burn Timer.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.13_msg_1: Maneuvers are invaluable when you’re trying to leave Kerbin. Feel free to come back and practice!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.14_msg_1:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to set a target.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to create a maneuver.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to manipulate a maneuver.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.1_msg_1: Our rocket is in orbit over Kerbin and ready to fly. The mission today is to, drum roll please... intercept and orbit the Mun! To be captured by the Mun's gravity, our vessel must cross into the Mun’s sphere of influence or SOI - the zone in which its gravity is stronger than any other celestial body around it.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.2_msg_1: We’re going to create a maneuver plan to figure out when and how long we need to fire our engines to intercept the Mun. Enter Map View by pressing .
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.35:
Right now, our camera is following our vessel as it orbits Kerbin. Let's adjust our camera until we can see the Mun! Then, right click to target it.

<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Open the context menu by right-clicking the Mun.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.3_msg_1: Great! Now here’s a new trick: we can select any object as a target in Map View. Targeting gives some useful information and enables new tools. Once we've targeted a celestial body or other object in space, our maneuver will provide closest-pass and plane angle information. This can be very helpful for meeting up with someone or something in space.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.4_msg_1: <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Target the Mun by selecting Set Target.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.5.5: Second, remember how increasing velocity raises the opposite side of our orbit? Since we’re placing this maneuver plan where we intend to start our burn, we should put it on the opposite side of Kerbin from where we intend to intercept the Mun.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.5_msg_1:
We want to place this maneuver plan with two things in mind:
  
First, the Mun is in motion! We can’t aim our spacecraft where the Mun is right now. Instead, we have to aim where the Mun will be after our vehicle has coasted all the way from Kerbin.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.6_msg_1:
Placing a maneuver plan usually involves making a best guess and then fiddling with the maneuver until you get an intercept. Fortunately, you’ve got a crack navigator with you today. By my calculations, we want to put our maneuver here!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Open the context menu by left-clicking the point near the Periapsis.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.8_msg_1: Excellent! We’ve just created a Maneuver Plan! While we could find out if our departure timing is correct by just picking a direction and maxing the throttle, a maneuver plan tells us in advance how much Delta-V we’ll need, how long we’ll need to burn, and in what direction our vessel will need to point during the maneuver.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.1.9_msg_1: Grab and pull the arrows to plan a burn along that direction. This maneuver is pretty simple: we want to burn prograde and expand our orbit. Create a maneuver plan to intercept the Mun by left-clicking and pulling the prograde marker.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.10_msg_1: Okay, get ready to hit the throttle…
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.11_msg_1:
And go! Fire those engines!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Press Z or hold shift to set Throttle to 100%.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.12_msg_1: Watch the burn timer! We want to stop our burn once it reaches 0!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.13_msg_1:
Everything’s looking great! Cut the throttle!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set Throttle to 0% by pressing X or holding Ctrl.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.14_msg_1: Great work! You’ve successfully executed a maneuver, and now we’re on our way to the Mun!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.15_msg_1:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to warp to a maneuver.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to aim a vessel for a maneuver.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to execute a maneuver.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.1_msg_1: We’ve got a maneuver plan that intercepts the Mun. Now we just need to execute that maneuver and fly to the Mun ourselves!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.2_msg_1: <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Enter Map View by pressing <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=77></voffset></mspace>.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.3_msg_1: Whenever we have a maneuver plan, a Burn Timer will appear. The timer shows you how much time is left until we need to execute the maneuver. I’ve paused the simulation for a moment, so this number won’t count down quite yet.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.4_msg_1: The timer also tells us how long we’ll need to burn our engines at 100% throttle in order to complete the maneuver.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.5_msg_1: Now let’s take a look at the navball. A new marker has joined our old prograde and retrograde markers. This is called a maneuver marker, and it shows us the orientation of our planned maneuver. We’ll want to make sure that this marker is in the center of our navball during our maneuver burn. Luckily, we can aim at this maneuver marker by selecting the maneuver button on your SAS controls. Orient your vessel to your maneuver using SAS.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.6_msg_1:
Now your vehicle is properly oriented! And through the magic of SAS and more math than I’d like to admit, our vessel is properly oriented!

We’re still far from our planned burn, so let’s speed things up!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.7_msg_1: While we could rely on our reflexes to time warp at the perfect moment, a less stressful alternative is warping to a specific point in our orbit. See this button? Select it to warp automatically to the moment before our maneuver begins. Warp to your maneuver by selecting the Maneuver Warp button.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2.9_msg_1: Great! We’ve exited just before our maneuver burn, and I’ve paused the simulation once more. After we select Continue, remember to wait until the countdown reaches 0. Then we'll go full throttle until our burn timer reaches 0, then cut the throttle quickly to avoid overshooting our target.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.2_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> The maneuver interface
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to aim a vessel for a maneuver
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to execute a maneuver
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.1.5: To orbit the Mun, we’ll need to burn retrograde once we’re inside its SOI or sphere of influence. This will slow us down enough to keep from being whipped into interplanetary space!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.10_msg_1:
The maneuver is right, and we’re pointed in the right direction, now we need to time warp to the right position!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Warp to our maneuver by selecting the Maneuver Warp button.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.12_msg_1: Almost there! When the countdown reaches zero, I will prompt you to throttle up to start your capture burn. On my mark!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.13_msg_1:
Throttle up now!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set Throttle to 100% by pressing Z or holding Shift.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.14_msg_1: Keep burning until the burn timer reaches 0!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.15_msg_1:
Shut down the engines now! We have an orbit!
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Set Throttle to 0% by pressing X or holding Ctrl.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.16_msg_1: Fantastic! That was some fancy flying! Looks to me like you’re about ready to try this for real!
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.17_msg_1:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That a vessel must slow down at its periapsis to be captured.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> How to plan and execute a capture burn.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.1_msg_1: It’s going to take a while to reach the Mun, but don’t let the wait fool you - we’re now moving faster than any Kerbal has ever flown before! When we enter the Mun’s sphere of influence, we'll be going way too fast for the Mun’s gravity to capture our vehicle.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.2_msg_1: <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Enter Map View by pressing <mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="Input-Keyboard" index=77></voffset></mspace>.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.3_msg_1: Let’s start by time warping until we’re within the Mun’s sphere of influence. That’s the sphere within which the Mun is the primary gravitational influence on your vehicle. Let’s get a little bolder with our time warp this time! Select 1000x Time Warp.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.5.5: Did you notice that we’ve got a periapsis above the Mun, but no apoapsis? That’s because we’re going too fast to complete an orbit before sailing past the Mun. Don’t worry, we have time to adjust. Our objective is to slow down enough so that both apoapsis and periapsis are within the Mun’s sphere of influence.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.5_msg_1: Welcome to the Mun’s sphere of influence! Let’s slow down to normal time so we can create our capture maneuver. Select 1x Time Warp.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.6_msg_1: Remember the rule of orbital opposites: because we want to lower your apoapsis, we’ll need to place our maneuver plan at the periapsis. Let’s get started! Open the context menu by left-clicking the orbit near the Periapsis icon.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.8_msg_1: In order to reduce our apoapsis, we need to slow down by burning backwards, or retrograde. This is a little like deorbiting over Kerbin, but we’re going to stop burning before our trajectory meets Mun dust. Create a maneuver that will orbit the Mun by pulling on the retrograde Arrow of the Maneuver Plan.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3.9_msg_1:
Maneuver plan set! Next up, let’s make sure we’re pointed where we need to be.
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Orient the vessel to our maneuver using SAS.
Tutorials/tutorial_5.3_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:
  
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That you need to slow down in order to be captured by another celestial body.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> Where to create a maneuver to be captured.
Tutorials/tutorial_5_failure_maneuver_ch: I assure you that my calculations are flawless, so please leave that maneuver node alone!
Tutorials/tutorial_5_failure_throttled_e: I like explosions too, but now isn’t the time to start your burn. Let’s try again!
Tutorials/tutorials_3.2.11_msg_1:
We're now in high orbit! The experiments we perform here will be worth more than those at Kerbin’s low orbit.
  
  The more difficult a place is to reach, the more valuable the research will be.
Tutorials/tutorials_5.0_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:

<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> The faster you go, the higher your orbit gets.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> In the Mun's sphere of influence, Mun's gravitational influence is stronger than Kerbin.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=1></voffset></mspace> Time your departure so that the Mun's SOI captures your vehicle at its highest point.
tutorial_1.2.4_msg_1: To break free of Kerbin’s soupy atmosphere, we want either a launcher or sustainer engine. I personally like sustainers. What can I say? They keep me going. Select the Engine Category in the Parts Menu.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.10_msg_1: There are two types of research reports: Data and Sample. Data reports can be transmitted back to KSC. Sample reports will need to be returned by recovering your vehicle at Kerbin.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.11_msg_1: Fortunately, we just got a Data report, so let’s transmit it! Transmit the Data Report.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.12_msg_1: Transmitting requires both Electric Charge (EC) and an antenna to communicate back to KSC. If you’re ever planning a one-way mission for science, make sure you have both.
FTUE/ftue_rnd_msg_1: This is the Research and Development Center! You can spend the Science you earn through missions and experiments to research new parts to build even cooler vehicles! If you're a fan of bigger, better engines, focus on the parts near the top of the tree.
FTUE/ftue_experiment_msg_1: You have a part on board that can perform an experiment! You can perform experiments and return them for Science. Whenever you go somewhere new, run experiments! If you want to learn more about doing experiments, go to the Training Center and play the Earning Science tutorial under Orbits Are Weird.
FTUE/ftue_first_purchasable_tech_msg_1: You’ve earned enough science to develop a new technology! When you’re ready, head over to the R&D Center to earn some new parts!
FTUE/ftue_research_report_msg_1: Performing experiments generates Science Reports, which can be returned home for Science!
FTUE/ftue_research_report_msg_2: You can review all of this flight’s Science Reports in the Research Inventory App. Data reports can be transmitted back home, and sample reports must be recovered on Kerbin.
FTUE/ftue_mission_control_msg_1: Welcome to Mission Control! Between you and me, Keri is a mission fanatic. Keri will automatically accept all missions, which leaves you to decide when and how to complete them! She's already got a mission for you! Select the mission in the Mission Log to see the objective.
FTUE/ftue_mission_control_msg_2: If you want more information about a mission, select Mission Brief. If you select Track Mission, then you can use the Mission Tracker App in flight to see the status of your objective. You can track as many missions as you want. Once you're all clear on what to do, go to the Vehicle Assembly Building to build a rocket to complete the mission!
FTUE/ftue_mission_control_msg_3: Congratulations! You have just met your first mission's objectives! Once your vehicle is safely landed on Kerbin, go to Mission Control to submit your mission report to Keri! If you do happen to have some crazy, time-reversing technology, like Revert, be aware that you may go back in time to a point that you have not completed this mission!
FTUE/ftue_mission_control_msg_4: You have a mission report that can be submitted! Select the mission in the Mission Log and then select Submit Mission.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1_summary:
Tutorial Complete! You have learned:

<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> To perform experiments.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> To transfer data to earn science.
<mspace=20><voffset=.3em><sprite="input-useractions" index=0></voffset></mspace> That samples must be brought back to KSC.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.1_msg_1: Have you seen our R&D building? Our brilliant scientists are constantly developing new technologies. New technology means new parts to play with! Exciting right? There is one teeny catch.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.2_msg_1: Our scientists don’t get out much. Outside of the launchpad, the majority of the KSC’s explosions happen at R&D. After “The Great Bathroom Break Incident,” the team has decided to stay put. Seriously, they’ve installed bunkbeds in the break room!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.3_msg_1: That’s where we come in! While our scientists are hard at work, it’s up to us to give them all the data they crave. Yes, I mean us. Who do you think pilots our probes?
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.4_msg_1: We earn Science by completing missions and performing experiments. Feel free to visit Mission Control for the rundown on missions. I’m here to guide you through performing experiments!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.5_msg_1: Experiments are performed at Research Locations, a combination of place and situation. For example, low orbit and high orbit around Kerbin are two of those locations! Other situations include being landed in a certain geographic region, swimming in the water, or flying in the atmosphere over Kerbin's majestic mountains.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.6_msg_1: Experiments are performed by special experiment parts. Each experiment will detail what Research Locations they work in, so read your part details in the VAB! Kerbals on Extravehicular Activity (EVA) are also able to perform experiments, but make sure they don’t lock the door behind them so they can re-enter the vehicle!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.7_msg_1: “But PAIGE,” you say, “that’s a lot to keep in mind. Is there an easy way to tell when I should perform an experiment?” I’ve got your back. Every experiment on your vessel is tied to the Perform Experiments button. It’s lit right now, so when you use it, it will activate our General Science Collection Module and let us know how the Mystery Goo is doing. Select the Perform Experiment button.
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.8_msg_1: It’s as easy as that! By the way, if you ever want to perform a specific experiment, or you want to see the status of an experiment, you can use the Part Action Manager. All of our experiments have been performed, and their research reports are available for us to read. Let’s see what we got!
Tutorials/tutorial_3.1.9_msg_1: The Research Inventory shows all research reports that are on our vessel. You can see what we’ve learned, how much it’s worth, and even transmit certain reports back to KSC!
Tutorials/Lessons/Descriptions/Tutorial: Learn how to perform experiments and return them to earn Science.
